pageDeck.heading: Colophon
paragraphs: Sing Chan is currently the VP of Product at Collabware Systems.

Sing is responsible for working with customers and stakeholders to determine the product and feature roadmaps for Collabware's Collabspace solution and manages the Product and Quality Assurance teams.
He is also responsible for the interaction design, user experience, and front-end development frameworks for Collabware's software offerings.

technologies.intro: This portfolio site has been rebuilt from the ground up. Here's what powers the current version:

items.name: Next.js 16
items.description: React framework with App Router for server-side rendering, static generation, and optimized performance.

items.name: React 19
items.description: UI library for building component-based interfaces with hooks and concurrent features.

items.name: TypeScript
items.description: Static type checking for improved developer experience and code reliability.

items.name: Material UI (MUI)
items.description: Comprehensive React component library implementing Material Design with customizable theming.

items.name: Emotion
items.description: CSS-in-JS library for styled components and dynamic styling.

items.name: Claude Code
items.description: AI-powered coding assistant for pair programming, code review, and documentation.

items.name: ESLint
items.description: JavaScript/TypeScript linter for code quality and consistency.

items.name: Prettier
items.description: Opinionated code formatter for consistent style.

items.name: Vitest
items.description: Fast, Vite-native unit test framework with excellent TypeScript support.

items.name: React Testing Library
items.description: Testing utilities focused on user behavior rather than implementation details.

technologies.v1Description: The original portfolio site was built with these technologies:

v1Items.name: Gumby Framework
v1Items.description: Responsive grid layout, Entypo icon set, and base UI element styles.

v1Items.name: jQuery
v1Items.description: Asynchronously loading portfolio projects, DOM manipulation, and UI effects.

v1Items.name: PHP
v1Items.description: Simple web service to serve up the portfolio projects.

v1Items.name: Swipebox
v1Items.description: jQuery plugin for the project image lightboxes.

v1Items.name: SWFObject
v1Items.description: Determined whether to show links to Adobe Flash projects.

v1Items.name: Sass & Compass
v1Items.description: Custom CSS written in SCSS syntax and compiled with Compass.

designPhilosophy.intro: The initial design was inspired by classic pork cuts diagrams. I wanted the site to feel like a menu at a butcher shop but eventually moved to a modern feel through the use of flat colours and sans-serif fonts.

colors.description: Cherry blossom pink - more inspirational than actual implementation

colors.name: Duck Egg
colors.description: Pastel green - used for secondary elements and tags

colors.name: Sky Blue
colors.description: Primary accent color for interactive elements

colors.name: Sage
colors.description: Muted green for the footer background

colors.name: Maroon
colors.description: Deep red for headings and call-to-action elements

designPhilosophy.colorDescription: The colour palette is comprised of some of my favourite pastels—sakura (cherry blossom), duck egg, and sky blue — graphite and maroon are included as background colours for instances of white text.

paragraphs: The well-dressed Buta (pig in Japanese) caricature found in the footer was created for me by Christine Ibbitson. Buta is a shameless rip-off of Yoshi Boo, or Boo-chan, a now retired mascot for Yoshinoya, a famous chain of fast food restaurants in Japan (and other parts of the world).

In early 2004, Yoshinoya introduced a pork-centric menu due to the rising cost of beef in Japan when U.S. beef imports were banned in December 2003 after a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy was reported in the United States. I take it the marketing folk at Yoshinoya decided the best way to promote their new pork-based menu was to create a new mascot.

When I went to Japan in March 2005, Yoshinoya was celebrating the 1-year anniversary of the introduction of their pork menu. Boo-chan was all over their in-store merchandising and there was a funny TV commercial of him dressed in a tuxedo giving a press conference. Boo-chan was an easy choice to become my new avatar.
